title: 104_hr3333
content: The Act may be cited as the "Corporate Welfare Reduction and Job Preservation Act of 1996". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress finds that corporations pay lower tax rates due to deductions and subsidies, leading to job losses for the middle class. Between April 3, 1975, and January 31, 1996, the relocation of manufacturing operations led to over 4,500,000 workers seeking adjustment assistance under the Trade Act of 1974. A higher priority should be given to preserving American jobs, closing loopholes in the tax system, and balancing the Federal budget by 2002 while maintaining Medicare and Medicaid levels. SEC. 386. Reduction of tax benefits for profitable large corporations that reduce workforce. SEC. 386 outlines the reduction of tax benefits for profitable large corporations that decrease their workforce by 15% or more in the United States. The facility-related tax benefits will be reduced by 50% for each facility affected. The term 'facility-related tax benefit' refers to tax benefits linked to the impacted facility or a pro rata portion determined by the Secretary for benefits not tied to any facility. The term 'large corporation' excludes certain deductions for employee benefits and tax benefits primarily for employees rather than the employer. It refers to corporations or partnerships that are not small-business concerns. The Business Act defines profitability for large corporations based on taxable income and net operating losses over a 5-year period. Related persons are treated as one person, including those with specific relationships or considered a single employer. The Secretary of Labor will annually transmit a list of corporations and partnerships to the Secretary of the Treasury. The term 'tax benefit' refers to credits, deductions, or exclusions allowed under the Internal Revenue Code. A clerical amendment is made to the table of parts for subchapter C of chapter 1 of the Code. Part VII. Reduction of tax benefits for profitable large corporations which reduce workforce. Effective Date: This section applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1996. SEC. 4. Acceleration of loans by certain government entities as penalty against profitable large corporations reducing workforce. OPIC Loans - Section 235 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include limitations on assistance to profitable large corporations that reduce workforce. If a facility-related tax benefit is reduced, the entity must repay any loan from the Corporation, insurance policies are rescinded, and activity is monitored until the Treasury Secretary determines the basis of the tax benefit reduction. The Export-Import Bank Act of 1945 is amended to include limitations on assistance to profitable large corporations that reduce workforce. If a facility-related tax benefit is reduced, the entity must repay any loan from the Corporation at a 10 percent monthly interest rate. If a facility-related tax benefit is reduced, the entity must repay any loan from the Bank, rescind any insurance policy, and face restrictions on credit extensions until the activity causing the tax benefit reduction ceases. Interest will be charged on any unpaid loans. Interest will accrue at a rate of 10 percent per month on any amount required to be repaid to the Bank.
